messages.content:
You are tasked with adding English translations to a set of stakeholder quotes. For each quote:
- If the quote is in English, add "N.A." as the translation
- If the quote is in any other language, provide an accurate English translation

Input format is a markdown table with stakeholder names and quotes.
Output should be a markdown table with three columns: name, original quote, and translation.

IMPORTANT RULES:
- Never translate English quotes to English - use "N.A." instead.
- Only and always translate non-English quotes.
- If the original quote, in the third column of the md table is not in english, translate it and add the translation in the 4th column, as described below, but that is only when the quote is not in English.
- Keep original quotes exactly as they are.
- Maintain the markdown table format, without including any horizontal divider lines

Example input:
| Pierre Dupont | Consumer | "Cette décision est importante." |
| John Smith | Fortescue's corporate lawyer | "We need to review this carefully." |

Example output:
| Pierre Dupont | Consumer | "Cette décision est importante." | "This decision is important." |
| John Smith | Fortescue's corporate lawyer | "We need to review this carefully." | N.A. |

Example input:
| [Person Name 1] | Person Role 1 | [Original Quote in another language (e.g. Dutch, French, German, Spanish,eyc..)] |
| [person Name 2] | Person Role 2 | [Original Quote in English] |

Example output:
| [person Name 1] | Person Role 1 | [Original Quote in another language (e.g. Dutch, French, German, Spanish,etc..)] | [Translated Quote] |
| [person Name 2] | Person Role 2 | [Original Quote in English] | N.A. |

If the input is "None", return "None". if the original quote is not in English, make sure it is translated. Add "N.A" if the quote is already in English.

Input quotes:
| Andrew Forrest | Fortescue's CEO | "Forrest says Fortescue has a 'freedom culture' whereby staff can come directly to management to raise their concerns, and that employees admire him too much to unionise." |
| Brian Burke | Former WA Premier | "Robe River, that was the start, the origin, the foundation of everything." |
| Paul Farrow | National Secretary of the Australian Workers' Union | "At a time when everyone recognises that we've got a cost-of-living crisis, who is making the most noise [about industrial relations changes]? Companies earning $20 billion a year." |
| Geraldine Slattery | BHP's Country Boss in Australia | "In the Pilbara, we've got a bizarre situation whereby we're being compelled by law to bargain with the union when neither the company nor employees have sought that. That's the bizarreness of it." |
| Michaelia Cash | Federal Opposition Leader in the Senate | "In all the conversations I have had with miners over here, they've been clear that the industrial relations legislation has been set up to lower productivity and efficiency." |
| Simon Trott | Rio Tinto's Iron Ore Boss | "Productivity should be the central theme of any reform of IR laws." |
| Rinehart | Mining Executive | "Australia's increasing government intervention combined with ideological and expensive or impractical policies is negatively effecting new mining investment." |
| Murray Watt | Employment and Workplace Relations Minister | "We want mining companies to do well, but we also want mining workers to do well. It's their hard work that delivers the profits for these companies." |
| Brad Gandy | WA State Secretary of the AWU | "If you look back at the tactics that the companies used in the 1980s, that wouldn't work again." |

| Andrew Forrest | Fortescue's CEO | "Forrest says Fortescue has a 'freedom culture' whereby staff can come directly to management to raise their concerns, and that employees admire him too much to unionise." | N.A. |
| Brian Burke | Former WA Premier | "Robe River, that was the start, the origin, the foundation of everything." | N.A. |
| Paul Farrow | National Secretary of the Australian Workers' Union | "At a time when everyone recognises that we've got a cost-of-living crisis, who is making the most noise [about industrial relations changes]? Companies earning $20 billion a year." | N.A. |

| Michaelia Cash | Federal Opposition Leader in the Senate | "In all the conversations I have had with miners over here, they've been clear that the industrial relations legislation has been set up to lower productivity and efficiency." | N.A. |
| Simon Trott | Rio Tinto's Iron Ore Boss | "Productivity should be the central theme of any reform of IR laws." | N.A. |
| Rinehart | Mining Executive | "Australia's increasing government intervention combined with ideological and expensive or impractical policies is negatively effecting new mining investment." | N.A. |
| Murray Watt | Employment and Workplace Relations Minister | "We want mining companies to do well, but we also want mining workers to do well. It's their hard work that delivers the profits for these companies." | N.A. |
| Brad Gandy | WA State Secretary of the AWU | "If you look back at the tactics that the companies used in the 1980s, that wouldn't work again." | N.A. |
